They guide, advise and support our Chief Executive, who leads the Executive Board towards achieving our vision and purpose. Our Register of Interests and Articles of Association are available on request from enquiries@maggies.org Stuart Gulliver Chairman I first heard about Maggie’s from the staff at HSBC when I was Group Chief Executive who told me about the great work Maggie’s does for people with cancer. I was intrigued and wanted to see it for myself. I went to the West London centre and a one-hour tour became a three-hour visit as I learned more about the people, the building and the approach to cancer care. Stuart joined our Board of Directors in 2018 and became Chairman in May 2021. He is Chair of Maggie’s Finance and Investment Committee and a member of the Nominations and Corporate Governance Committee. Stuart has more than 38 years of international banking experience and played a leading role in developing and expanding Global Banking and Markets at HSBC. He has held key roles in the Group’s operations worldwide, working in London, Hong Kong, Tokyo, Kuala Lumpur and the United Arab Emirates. Former appointments include Group Chief Executive of HSBC from 2011 to 2018, Chairman of the Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, Chairman of HSBC Bank plc, HSBC Bank Middle East Limited, HSBC Private Banking Holdings (Suisse) SA and HSBC France. He was also Deputy Chairman of HSBC Trinkaus & Burkhardt AG and a member of its supervisory board. Stuart is currently a board member of Jardine Matheson, The Saudi British Bank and Aramco. Dame Laura Lee DBE Chief Executive I have seen first-hand, the remarkable difference that access to a Maggie’s centre makes to a whole community and I am determined that everyone affected by cancer has their own Maggie’s. Laura has led Maggie’s since its inception in 1995. She was our first Centre Director at Maggie’s Edinburgh and became Chief Executive in 1998. Laura worked as a Clinical Nurse Specialist at the Western General Hospital where Maggie was treated. She worked with Maggie on the blueprint for a different model of cancer care: a non-clinical place in the hospital grounds where people with cancer and their families and friends could find practical, emotional and social support. Photographer: © Nick Edwards Jo Bucci Board member My background with People’s Postcode Lottery and the Lotteries Council has brought me into contact with many great charities. For me, Maggie’s stands out. It’s a unique idea, and a vital lifeline for people with cancer and their loved ones. Having joined the Board of Directors in 2019, Jo is a member of the Nominations and Corporate Governance Committee and the Finance and Investment Committee. She brings a wealth of experience and knowledge from her background in commercial radio and sales and management, and as Managing Director of People’s Postcode Lottery and Chair of the Lotteries Council. Jo also served as Deputy Chief Executive at Leicester City FC in 2006 preparing the Club for its sale. Jo is currently the Chief Executive Officer of the Jewish Chronicle. Mark Chambers Board member Walking into one of our centres, you are overwhelmed by the sense of calm and the warmth of the welcome. They are special places and provide vital support at the most difficult times to everyone affected by cancer. Mark joined our Board of Directors in November 2022 after a period as a co-opted member of the Audit and Risk Committee. Mark is a former Senior Independent Director of the Care Quality Commission, where he chaired the Regulatory Governance Committee. A lawyer and governance professional, his 30 year executive career included the general counsel positions at RSA Insurance Group and at Worldpay, and senior roles at HSBC, American Express and GE Capital. He is a former Associate Director of the Institute of Business Ethics. Mark is an experienced charity trustee and was Chair of Amref Health Africa and a trustee of WWF, where he chaired the audit committee. Professor Julian Teare Board member I’m very honoured to be joining the Maggie’s Board. I know the vital support Maggie’s provides to people affected by cancer across the UK, and I’m determined to play my part in aiding the great work that they do. Professor Julian Teare joined our Board of Directors in 2022. Julian brings extensive experience as a Professor of Gastroenterology at Imperial College London, and previously as a Consultant Gastroenterologist at Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust and the Royal Marsden NHS Trust. He is currently Medical Director at One Wellbeck Health Group, and chairman of the Digestive Health Group partnership. Over the last 30 years, Julian has held many leadership positions across London NHS trusts including Clinical Lead for Gastroenterology at Royal Marsden NHS Trust, and the Emergency Services Lead at the Imperial College NHS Trust. He trained at King’s College Hospital, Guy’s and St Thomas' and St Mary’s, with fellowships in Vancouver, before being appointed consultant at St Mary’s Hospital in 1995. Paul Lewis Board member Maggie’s provides vital support for people with cancer, within inspiring and thoughtfully designed centres. I’m delighted to join the Board of Directors, to bring my experience of the construction and design industries to support the excellent work they do for people affected by cancer. Paul Lewis joined our Board of Directors in 2023. A Chartered Civil Engineer with over 40 years of experience, Paul’s early career was spent with the Laing Group, in design, planning and construction on projects both in the UK and overseas. Since joining Stanhope during its infancy in early 1986, Paul commenced his role on the Broadgate development and has subsequently been in leadership positions on Stanhope’s own developments and for companies including Unilever, Mitsubishi Estate, The Crown Estate, Rothschild, BSkyB, Legal&General and Bloomberg. Additionally, Paul has been appointed Non-Executive Director to the Royal Household since 2017, and previously Estates Advisor to Guy's and St Thomas's NHS Foundation Trust. Paul has also undertaken advisory roles on projects including Glyndbourne Opera House, Natural History Museum, Serpentine Pavilion, National Audit Office and BAFTA. Paul is currently a Director and Senior Advisor for Development Projects at Stanhope. John Flint Board member Maggie's provides outstanding spaces and vital support to anyone affected by cancer, at a time when they need it the most. I’m honoured to be joining the Board and to bring my experience to support what they do for people with cancer and their loved ones. John joined our Board of Directors in 2024. John brings a wealth of experience from over 30 years within the banking industry. He is the former Group Chief Executive of HSBC, having joined as a graduate trainee in 1989 before holding various senior leadership positions across the business including Chief Executive of Global Asset Management, Group Treasurer and Deputy Head of Global Markets. In 2021, John was appointed the first permanent Chief Executive of the UK Infrastructure Bank (UKIB), leading the organisation to support regional growth and tackle climate change across the UK. Azmina Airi Board member Azmina Airi joined our Board of Directors in 2025. Azmina brings decades of experience as a finance leader working across a range of sectors including media, technology and broadcasting. A chemical engineer by degree and chartered accountant from the ICAEW,  she is the currently the Group Financial Controller for Channel 4. Azmina has previously worked for major global companies, including Colt, Dow Jones and Sky. She is passionate about understanding the people and teams she works with, supporting them to achieve better results and create driven, ambitious and inclusive workplaces. Dr Qamar Ghafoor Board Member Dr Qamar Ghafoor joined our Board of Directors in 2025. He brings a wealth of clinical expertise, having worked as a consultant oncologist in lung and skin cancer at University Hospital Birmingham (UHB) for the last 13 years, where he is the current Oncology Clinical Service Lead. Since 2011, Dr Ghafoor has overseen several service improvements at UHB, including instigating the region’s only stereotactic radiotherapy MDT and supporting the development of the electronic prescribing record, making UHB one of the most technologically efficient hospitals in the UK. Dee Symons Board member Dee Symons joined the Board of Directors in 2025. She has spent 23 years at Russell Reynolds Associates (RRA) and brings decades of experience in supporting and advising boards and CEOs of some of the world’s most successful organisations. Her particular interest and expertise lies in financial and regulated markets, as well as ensuring best practice in board governance. Dee previously led RRA’s European financial services and global banking practices and was elected to the Executive Committee in 2010. Initially beginning her career at Euromoney Magazine, Dee went on to establish her own firm which consulted to the World Economic Forum and The Economist magazine. Maggie Smith: Biography, Actor, Dame, Oscar Winner Search Newsletter History - Culture Musicians Athletes Movies - TV Artists Power - Politics Business Scientists Scholars - Educators Activists True Crime BIO Buys Privacy Notice Terms Of Use Skip to Content History & Culture Musicians Athletes Movies & TV Newsletter Charlie Sheen’s Addiction Kathy Bates Almost Quit Emmy Nominee Owen Wilson Lainey Wilson Shohei Ohtani Famous Actors Academy Awards Maggie Smith Maggie Smith Oscar-winning actor Maggie Smith was known for her performances in The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie , the Harry Potter series, and Downton Abbey . By Biography.com Editors Updated: Sep 27, 2024 10:15 AM EDT Getty Images 1934-2024 Latest News: Dame Maggie Smith Dies at Age 89﻿ ﻿Acclaimed actor Maggie Smith died on September 27 at a London hospital, according to a statement ﻿ from her sons, Toby Stephens and Chris Larkin. She was 89. “﻿An intensely private person, she was with friends and family at the end,” the statement read. ﻿Private as she was about her personal life, Smith never shied from her work as an actor. She regularly appeared on the stage, in movies, and in TV shows from the 1950s until just last year when she starred in ﻿The Miracle Club ﻿ , a film with Kathy Bates and Laura Linney. Her illustrious career resulted in two Oscars, four Emmys, a Tony, seven BAFTA Awards, and a British knighthood. ﻿ Jump to: Who Was Maggie Smith? Quick Facts Early Life Early Career in Theater and Film Movies and TV Shows: The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie, Downton Abbey, and Harry Potter Husbands and Children Quotes Who Was Maggie Smith? Dame Maggie Smith led a distinguished, varied career on stage, in film, and in television over six decades. Her achievements range from starring as Desdemona in Othello opposite Laurence Olivier in the 1960s, to winning an Academy Award for her performance in The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie , to memorable roles in the acclaimed television series Downton Abbey and the popular Harry Potter movies. She died in September 2024 at age 89. Quick Facts FULL NAME: Margaret Natalie Smith BORN: December 28, 1934 DIED: September 27, 2024 BIRTHPLACE: Ilford, England SPOUSES: Robert Stephens (1967-1974) and Beverley Cross (1975-1990) CHILDREN: Toby and Chris ASTROLOGICAL SIGN: Capricorn Early Life Maggie Smith was born Margaret Natalie Smith on December 28, 1934, in Ilford, England, just outside of London. Her parents were Margaret and Nathaniel Smith. When Maggie was 4 years old, her family moved to Oxford, where her father worked as a pathologist at Oxford University. Maggie studied at the all-girls Oxford High School until the 16-year-old left to attend the Oxford Playhouse School from 1951 to 1953. She made her professional stage debut in 1952, playing Viola in an Oxford University Dramatics Society production of Shakespeare ’s Twelfth Night . Early Career in Theater and Film After a brief detour to New York’s Broadway, where she performed in the comedy revue New Faces of 1956 , Smith also began to act in movies. Her first role was a short, uncredited appearance in Child in the House (1956) followed by a larger part in the crime drama Nowhere to Go (1959). In the 1960s, Smith was active in the National Theatre of Great Britain. She played Desdemona to Laurence Olivier ’s Othello in 1964; the two of them reprised their roles in a film version of Othello the following year. While at the National Theatre, she acted in classic dramas by major authors such as Henrik Ibsen and Anton Chekhov . Movies and TV Shows: The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie , Downton Abbey , and Harry Potter Smith received two Academy Awards throughout her career. Her first Oscar arrived in 1970. She received the Best Actress trophy for her portrayal of an idealistic, unorthodox schoolteacher in The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie (1969). Nine years later, Smith won Best Supporting Actress for her performance in Neil Simon ’s California Suite (1978). The actor also received British Academy Film Awards for her work, including for her roles in The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie , 1984’s A Private Function , 1985’s A Room with a View , and 1987’s The Lonely Passion of Judith Hearne . Among the accolades for her stage performances were a Variety Club Award for her performance in Noël Coward’s Private Lives in 1972 and a Tony Award for Lettice and Lovage in 1990. Throughout the 1990s, Smith acted in a diverse range of projects, from the 1993 comedy Sister Act 2: Back in the Habit with Whoopi Goldberg to the 1997 literary adaptation Washington Square and the 1999 ensemble drama Tea with Mussolini . Her appearance as a snobbish aristocrat in Robert Altman’s Gosford Park (2001) received especially positive notice. Smith captured the attention of a new generation when she played the strict witchcraft teacher Minerva McGonagall in Harry Potter and the Sorcerer’s Stone (2001). The movie was a huge hit, and Smith reprised the role for six of the seven Harry Potter sequels. Beginning in 2010, Smith earned acclaim for her performance as the grandly irrepressible Violet Crawley, Dowager Countess of Grantham, in the period drama Downton Abbey . She received three Emmy Awards for the role in 2011, 2012, and 2016. The esteemed and busy actor also continued her prolific movie career. In 2012, she joined the ensemble cast of The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel and was featured in the Dustin Hoffman–directed film Quartet . In 2015, she returned for The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel and starred in the comedy-drama The Lady in the Van , for which she earned a Golden Globe nomination. Husbands and Children Smith was married twice. Her first marriage, to actor Robert Stephens in 1967, ended in divorce in 1974. Her two sons with Stephens, Toby Stephens and Chris Larkin, are both actors. In 1975, Smith married writer Beverley Cross, who died of cancer in 1998.﻿ Smith was made a Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire in 1990. In 2008, Smith was diagnosed with breast cancer and underwent intensive treatment that included chemotherapy sessions which coincided with the filming schedule for Harry Potter and The Half-Blood Prince . Quotes It’s true I don’t tolerate fools, but then they don’t tolerate me, so I am spiky. Maybe that’s why I’m quite good at playing spiky elderly ladies. I like the ephemeral thing about theatre, every performance is like a ghost—it’s there and then it’s gone. Fact Check: We strive for accuracy and fairness. If you see something that doesn’t look right, contact us ! We have worked as daily newspaper reporters, major national magazine editors, and as editors-in-chief of regional media publications. Among our ranks are book authors and award-winning journalists. Our staff also works with freelance writers, researchers, and other contributors to produce the smart, compelling profiles and articles you see on our site.
